document.docAuthor: Menzel, Frank, Smith, Jane E. & Chandler, Peter J.
document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 146 (1)
document.masterDocTitle: The sciarid fauna of the British Isles (Diptera: Sciaridae), including descriptions of six new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The sciarid fauna of the British Isles (Diptera: Sciaridae), including descriptions of six new species
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph:
Literature :? Walker (1848) : 108 [as
Sciara sylvatica
(recte
silvatica
)]; Basden (1933) : 44 [as
Sciara modesta
, misidentification]; Freeman (1983b) : 36; Laurence (1994) : 116 [in part as
Bradysia triseriata
, misidentification]; Menzel (1998): 20; Chandler (2001) : 200 [all as
Bradysia amoena
]; Menzel & Heller (2005) : 351 [
amoena (Winnertz)
as synonym to
tilicola (Loew)
].

Ecological notes : found in damp broad-leaved and alder carr woodland; pine plantations; moorland; wetlands including fen, bog, sedge bed and valley mire; gardens; grounds of horticultural research station; school grounds with old poplars; open montane habitats; in house; in greenhouse; house-plant compost, in old bird nest. Reared from fungi
Amanita muscaria
,
Gymnopilus junonius
,
Inonotus cuticularis
,
Lepiota cristata
, under dead poplar bark, larva under pine bark, tulip bulbs, decaying onions, formicarium, and soil from rabbit burrow. Larvae found destroying young seedlings of ling (
Calluna vulgaris
) and bulbs of lily (
Lilium aurantiacum
); in gerbil cage. i–xii.

Taxonomic note : Loew found
Sciara tilicola
in large numbers. From the apparently large type series, only 2 males with the original labelling ‘
tilicola Lw.
’ could still be found in the Loew collection. The lectotype designation in Menzel & Heller (2005) conforms with the interpretation of Lengersdorf (1928 –30: 52), who considered that
tilicola Loew
is identical with
amoena Winnertz
but listed the species under the incorrect name ‘
modesta Staeger, 1840
’. Further information about the type material of
tilicola (Loew)
and about the synonymy of
amoena (Winnertz)
can be found in Menzel & Heller (2005) .
